sourceOfFunds.purpose: Bharat Life Foundation is working for poor girl marriage,, mainly to perform the adopt of daughters whose families cant afford a wedding. We try to support the girl and her family by bearing the expenses of the wedding and demolish dowry and suicide due to lack of funds for marriage. We believe that no girl should be treated as a burden just due to her marriage expense. we aim to provide all the funds required for a wedding and help such families and brides.

overty and lack of housing are some of the realities faced by children orphaned by HIV/AIDS in India. Providing quality houses to those who require them should not be the sole responsibility of the Department of Human Settlements. Companies (through corporate social investment programmes), contributors, NGOs and other Members within the communities, should work together with Bharat Life Foundation to provide houses to the poor.

We are trying that every needy women should have their own house, keeping this in view, a commendable effort is being made by Bharat Life Foundation to provide free housing plots to the needy women. Under this scheme, Jaipur has been included in the first phase in the districts of Rajasthan for land allotment. Under the scheme, plots will be available in 111, 100 and 50 square yards, which will be allotted by Bharat Life Foundation to needy women.

The member/artisans of the Foundation have also participated in India Trade Fair at Pragati Maidan and Dilli Haat, Lucknow, Hyderabad, Nagpur and various other parts of India. Bharat Mata Welfare Foundation is also providing educational, medical, cultural, environmental, social, computer training etc. facilities to the poor and backward community of the society.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: The people residing in slum & backward locality of North East Delhi face numerous problems and many of them gradually become victims of drug addiction and slip from bad to worse. The Sanstha has successfully bridged the gap between the Govt. and the beneficiaries and reached out drug addicts in getting them rid of their addiction habits besides working out for their rehabilitation. Keeping in view the huge need/ demand the 15 bedded de addiction centre was upgraded to 30 bedded de addicts centre. The sanstha has been associated in this field adopting various majors such as distribution of pumplets and leaflets, organizing services and group discussions, generating awareness campaign, visiting door to door of the dwellers etc. To tackle this psycho-socio-medical problem the sanstha has successfully adopted the approach of awareness generation, identification, treatment and rehabilitation. The thrust is on preventive educative programme to convert addicts as a normal person into the main stream of society. Addiction sanstha in collaboration with DSACS is running successfully the target intervention project for ameliorating the condition of injecting drug user and female sex workers and sanstha has helped more than 15000 injecting drug users and female sex workers. Such populace carries the high risk of sexually transmitted diseases and HIV/AIDS hence they require special intervention, focus and follow up of the trained staff of Sanstha. Besides above our sanstha is an accredited vocational institution of National Institute of Open Schooling and sanstha imparts vocational training to women empowerment in garment and beauty culture which has benefitted the ladies/girls of poor families living in slums. The Sanstha has also carried out a campaign for the health checkup of school children under Chacha Nehru Sehat Yojana wherein during the year 2013-14 about 47,000 school children in Delhi have been screened. The sanstha has also carried out a campaign for Awareness to Rural consumers in 5 districts of Bihar namely Patna, Vaishali, Arval, Mujjafarpur and Nalanda during the year 2013-14 in collaboration with Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Govt. of India.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Caritas Indias biggest achievement lies in the fact that it is Indias second largest network organization after Red Cross. What makes us unique is our presence across the country and the large spectrum of development interventions for which Caritas India mobilizes and invests funds. Last year, Caritas India was recognized one among twenty reputed innovative organizations that received the Millennium Alliance award Round two for innovation from Honorable Transport Minister Nitin Gadkare. Caritas India also has successfully conducted four major International Conference on Food Security, Small holder Farmers, Disaster Risk Reduction, Child Rights and is now going to organize a National Conference on Health and Well-Being. Caritas India CBRF was formed during 1996 and since then it works with partner NGOs to promote empowerment and inclusion of persons with disabilities in rural areas through Community Based rehabilitation approach. Currently it is reaching out to 52,000 people with disabilities through 65 NGO partners. Apart from this, we have worked on projects that aim at improving the living standards of communities like displaced tribal community in Tripura, endosulfan victims in Mangalore, marginalized community of Jammu etc. These target population were given training on skill development on activities like driving, jewelry making, goat and pig rearing, tailoring, mushroom cultivation.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: 1. Effect of Zinc Supplementation on acute diarrhoea, persistent diarrhoea and dysentery of young children led to revision of program recommendations to include zinc as a treatment for diarrhoea by WHO, UNICEF, IAP

sourceOfFunds.purpose: Project Started on 21/06/2016. During FY 16-17 the support structure was setup. Amount sanctioned is for entire Study Duration. Project Objectives: 1. To Compare rates of all-Cause mortality 2. To compare the average change in linear growth in the 90 days following an episode of high risk diarrhoea without dysentery among children 2 to 23 months of age living in low resource settings who are randomized to receive a 3-day course of azithromycin , a 3-day course of ciprofloxacin or placebo.

PROJECT OBJECTIVES: 1. To evaluate the non-inferiority of lower Zinc doses (10 mg/day and 5 mg/day) versus standard Zinc Dose (20 mg/day) regarding diarrhoea (duration of symptoms, and risk of diarrhoea > 5 days) 2. ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: In 2011, Centre for Holistic Development-CHD emerged in Delhi as one of the few on the street workers working with the homeless Citizens with an emphasis on leadership and capacity building within the homeless community. Prior experience of anchoring the UNDP survey on homeless people in Delhi in 2010 equipped the now formed CHD to take its work forward. Though based in Delhi CHD aspires to work all over India in the coming future. CHD aims to build a self sustainable environment of community care and social inclusion for Homeless Citizens through a rights based approach ensuring a better quality of life. It works towards building safe, community care giving spaces for the homeless citizens through increased participation by establishing their identity as citizens and ensuring access to shelter, food, health, hygiene, safety, privacy, legal powers and freedom from oppression and violence. Scope of work: We have managed, in our short term, to work in all 11 revenue districts in Delhi touching a population of over 80,000 people approximately of the 1.5 lakh homeless population of the city. This includes all areas of public transactions like railways, bus stops and markets. We also work with 5000 porters all over Delhi, in their work and living areas and plan to scale this work to porters all over India. Presently CHD is involved with on street night vigilance accompanied with aid and emergency services. These interventions span over the following themes while engaging with urban poverty. A crucial aspect of CHDs work is the night vigilance that it does to ensure security of and aid provision to the homeless citizens. Aid can be in terms of provision of immediate food and shelter, medical aid, legal aid, intervention with the police or emergency aid depending on the situation. At the present moment CHD reaches out to three emergency interventions per day. Since December 2013, 10 pregnant and lactating women have been provided with shelter, 10 children have been put under shelter care through the CWC and 5 homeless women have been repatriated with their families. Given the nature of work being situational CHD maintains a network with 80,000 homeless citizens and works towards their day to day needs. Need for Night Vigil: Going by government records there are many seasonal deaths and the number tolls higher every year. CHD in collaboration with SAM-BKS took out a report on the basis of the night vigils conducted which estimated the death toll on Delhi streets as follows: - Between 1st September 2013 to 23rd January 2014 to be 1113, most of whom were homeless. - Between 1st April 2013 to 30th June 2013 to be 835 which has risen to 935 deaths during the same time frame in 2014. The report elucidating winter deaths compelled the NHRC to send out a notice to the Delhi Government. At the time the Delhi Government erected 70 more shelters in response during the winter. However, the number of shelters are not even close to addressing the issue of homelessness or the needs of the homeless citizens.

ngoList.title: Centre for Indian Classical Dances
ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Achievements of CICD The Centre for Indian Classical Dances (CICD) was founded in 1977 and since then has built its credibility and reputation on the merit of the quality of dance education imparted, activities undertaken and its emphasis on a holistic and socially integrated presentation of dance and other art forms of India. CICD is furthering the cause of promotion of Indian classical dances not only in India but all over the world. CICD is selflessly providing training and dissemination of knowledge and cultural traditions of India. CICD has continuously been presenting new choreographies every year on Indias Republic Day/Independence Day and many other occasions. They have been admired by one and all not only in India but also abroad. There has been continuous demand for presentations by Centres senior disciples. It is a proof of the value and authority of the training being imparted at the Centre. The training brings the disciples to a level of professionalism with which they are able to perform, teach and be useful to the society in many other ways. Centre has been in the forefront of Indias cultural institutions since 1977 when there were just 4-5 such institutions in Delhi. CICD organized annual festivals in which reputed dancers from all over India participated, festivals for young dancers in which Leela Samson, Saswati Sen, Bharati Shivaji, Kishan Mohan etc. were seen in Delhi. CICD organized meaningful seminars in the decades of 1970, 80, 90s in which Gurus like Prof U S Krishna Rao, Smt. Jayalaxmi, Smt. Mrinalini Sarabhai, Chandralekha, Dr. Kapila Vatsyayana etc. participated. Centre has since inception set many hallmarks and ideas which have been taken up and emulated by later dancers and their organizations. CICD practiced the policy of Gurukula system and also provided free tutitions/classes/ guidance to economically Backward children from NGOs like Sulabh & Deepalaya. CICDs productions have addressed issues like Jail Reforms, Environment, Womens Rights, Child-trafficking etc. CICD today retains its position in the front ranks of socio-cultural institutions of India.

ngoList.detailsOfAchievement: Strategies for Mapping Traditional & Cultural Skills  Honorary work as Knowledge Body with National Skill Development Corporation - NSDC , Various papers were presented to NSDC on: Defining Areas of Traditional and Cultural Skills, Methods to conduct survey and data collection Methods of tabulating data on Traditional and Cultural Skills, Methods to interpret data , Methods to launch pilot projects on sustainable livelihood related to: Displaced Street & Folk performance skills, skills related to Handmade paper, Skills related to Traditional Medicinal Plants , Skills related to Block printing. Creating Primary Health work program on Maternity Health in Border Areas of Ladakh and Assam by capacity building of Traditionally Skilled Communities associated with this sector: initiating a pilot program to address Reproductive Health by re-positioning Traditional skilled communities engaged in primary health and healing. Seminar on- Economics of Culture and Social Innovation for Safeguarding Intangible Heritage: Building Sustainable Livelihood Programs. Traditional Skills & Tourism : CNP was called by UP Tourism to advice on creating sustainable, responsible tourism strategies in the state of Uttar Pradesh
